children.subject: Do you think these lower capacities will be unique to Spring 2021? Or will they continue in future semesters? Will the EECS department get more funding in the future?
Like we still have to take classes right
(i'm scared because I have a pretty late enrollment time slot :(
There are too many students taking CS classes right now. Will the department consider hiring more lecturers? The department has to take some actions (either restrict enrollment or hire more faculty).
Lecturers also cost more money lol
But cost less than Professors. With lecturers, we could open more classes. There are almost no 16X classes for SP21 right now.

I think one cost saving measure could be to get rid of having to hire a new lecturer/professor every semester entirely. Classes could adopt the same teaching style as CS W186: have efficient, pre-recorded lectures with checks for understanding sprinkled in.  

Not having a real lecturer would allow more funding for more TAs, who are the real backbone of CS courses at Berkeley. There would still have to be someone that would assign grades and manage the TAs, though.
Spring 2021 Semester In the Could: your professor is a Could.
*Cloud. f autocomplete.

<md>I had a longer response that somehow got eaten, but in the case of something like W186: Lecturers themselves are not really that much cheaper than professors (though to the department there's different pros and cons due to arcane duding models). The real problem is finding people to teach courses where their job is ostensibly to put in minimal effort and do all the not fun parts of teaching. W186 is a great course with a great staff, but it's not enjoyable to "teach". Building W courses are way more work, and even then they still really deserve constant upkeep. W186 would be a better course with more faculty involvement, and the TAs deserve that too.

To be clear, it's certainly a useful tool, but it's no panacea. </md>

>Wait, so what happens to the students? 

"EECS leadership hears your concerns regarding the lower projected enrollment capacities. We will in any case ensure that wherever we land with enrollments, students are not hindered from graduating on time."
Wait, so what happens to the students?
You might find Prof. Sahai’s response in @7969 to be useful regarding the "what can we do about it" issue.
Yeah I read that response..but I am not exactly sure on how we should communicate these concerns to campus?
<md>email carol and you will get a response similar to what i received (nothing)</md>

@Anon Scale TBH, not 100% sure myself, especially with us being online. I'd venture a guess that if the university administration hears from a large number of students about the issue, they'd start to think it's a bigger problem. If every single student in the EECS/CS department (~3000 of us IIRC) reached out, even just to send a boilerplate email someone wrote up about what the problem is and what the proposed solution is e.g. in terms of how to reallocate funds (I think Prof. Sahai's point in @7969 about engineers not just complaining, but offering solutions is particularly salient), I'd imagine that'd send quite a message.
I understand your point, Dominic. It makes a lot of sense. But I feel to suggest budget re-allocation, we need to know how the budget is currently being allocated.
<md>anywhere NOT towards UG/graduate academic life</md>

I agree with @Anon Scale here, I believe some transparency about how our tuition money is divided will allow us to know what issues we should address and how we can advocate for more student-oriented support structures such as more TA's. In the meantime, I plan on talking to my professors during their office hours and learning more about this situation.

@Anon Scale I couldn't agree more. I certainly haven't done the requisite research to write up the kind of boilerplate message I mentioned in my previous response. I'm simply saying that if someone's interested in trying to contact the administration, and doing all the homework to put forward a coherent and well thought out suggestion, that'd be one way to go about it.

I really feel EECS as a department, needs to have a student body that can come together in such times to support the department or at least convey the department's message to the larger EE/CS/EECS community so that the students know what they need to do. My roommate was a MechE major and they used to have townhalls/student body meets, to discuss departmental issues. I am not sure if EECS has something like this, beyond HKN/UPE. This will also make it easier to have communication with ASUC, which can more easily transfer our concerns to campus. And this will make actions suggested by Dominic more actionable and implementable.

<md>Starting with fellow students though can be helpful. Find ASUC senators and ask them to forward your message to admins/staff. I can try to share more later, but none of these solutions are "one and done" either. There's organizing that can be done at every level -- hyper local to school deans and committees that have some power, to the the Chancellor, to UC, to the state. The smaller you go, the more likely you are to get a response. I'll just add that as Sahai's post indicates these are years-long problems that we keep working around, but so far have avoided some of the most problematic effects of budget cuts.

And to be clear about knowing: I some cases you don't need to know to make an initial argument to authority. Focus on why the current situation is harmful, and you can then follow up after you get a response and research that. (A live real time debate would be different, but we're building a case over time, not all at once.) It's an arcane system but CalAnswers does have some public budget data. </md>

Hello,

Thank you for sharing this information with us. May I ask why there will be significant funding cuts EECS will be using towards teaching support staff?

As a transfer student taking the lower division EECS classes, OH lines can often take up to an hour with 10+ students on the waiting list and approximately only 3 TA's assisting these students. This puts a strain on the TA's and also hampers the ability to assist students in a timely manner.

I am worried that many students will feel like they won't have the tutoring resources necessary to succeed next Spring. Online learning has been especially challenging for students like myself, who learn best in a collaborative environment. From my experience of this semester, the TA's and uGSI's are huge contributors to my education in this online environment.

If anything, I believe the EECS department should be putting more money into the EECS teaching staff -- especially since Spring 2021 will be online.

Please let me know if I can contact someone at the institution, I'd like to learn more about this situation. Thank you for your time and feel free to contact me at thanhtran@berkeley.edu

Sincerely,

Thanh
<md>while the funding to eecs department is lower, as a out-of-state (technically, i'm international student) i do pay more to uc, yay</md>
No. You just have to take classes over the summer now.
i meant those of us graduating next sem, but you have a good point.
for those of us trying to get a CS minor... we're basically screwed, right?
How much smaller are course sizes? What is the magnitude of these cuts?
Jesus I can't believe it's coming to this.
People are already making GoFundMe's for healthcare costs, student loans, now our entire department shows up on there...
Just auction off 10 slots per class and have that pay for another lecturer.

<md>I feel pretty conflicted about the idea of encouraging current students to donate, unless y'all are selling start ups or something. ;) But you should feel free to share this!
https://give.berkeley.edu/#Computer%20Science</md>

I understand people wanting to help support the department. But my greatest conflict is that I don't understand how the administration keeps on cutting the budget of departments while our tuition only goes up. It is contradicting and lacks transparency. I don't argue to necessarily lower tuition (although that would be nice), but instead, if there is money being paid and invested, then why do we have continues cuts? especially in a time when students need even more academic support for distance learning.
Is there any way students may donate directly to the EECS department rather than to the college as a whole?
<md>Additional courses are not likely, as they're not offered primarily due to faculty constraints AND are also subject to the budget constraints.</md>
The 161 instructors are trying to get it offered in the spring, but no guarantees.
<md>I avoided saying that about 161, because _really_ there are no guarantees. But, yes, there are interests in offering more courses, it's just a sizable challenge.</md>
I was the same. Super disappointed in the university for doing this. Hopefully we at least get some predictable rotation in classes so we can manage prerequisites.
Is it possible adding more CS courses for Spring 2021? I would like to take CS161 and CS168 next semester, but these courses are not available now.
Time for a protest! more funds for higher education! Just saying.
This isn't the place to ask that. Make a separate post and it's likelier that someone will be able to respond meaningfully
I have an issue where I am trying to enroll in CS61B, but it will not let me even though it allows time conflicts. How can I sign up even though CalCentral won't let me?
@13405 From here you can see it was a faculty vote that decided this.

I am curious why there are no reserved seats for junior/senior CS students for ee16b. I did not take it my fresh or soph year and now there are no reserved seats left that I can fall into. It seems unfair that I may not be able to graduate because I am on the waitlist for ee16b, a large CS major requirement, which should probably reserve seats for older students. What is the reasoning behind this, and are they going to expand capacity or give more reserved seats?

<md>"We will in any case ensure that wherever we land with enrollments, students are not hindered from graduating on time. "

Does this mean we could see changing graduating requirements?</md>
Anonymous Atom 3, how many CS Upper divs have you already taken? Can you maybe take a technical elective instead? A Math or Stats upper div could be very fun and interesting!

<md>I need 8 more units of CS Upper Divs in the cs department, I have some ideas for technical elective so im not too worried about that. Currently on my list is hoping I get into CS 184 off of the waitlist. </md>

<md>Implying I can even get on the waitlist for 184 lol
</md>

That is unfortunate. Do be careful 184 is another high workload class, alongside 170/162/189, so the department doesn't recommend doubling up on those courses.

Maybe you can look into taking an EE/EECS course? Like EE 120, EECS 126, EECS 127 are all entry level upper divs that are interesting and quite popular. EE 120 out of the three I would say is the lowest workload, so could be nice to take especially if you need it as a grad requirement and cannot get into CS 184 OR find it too demanding with CS 162.

<md>Yeah that was my worry with 162, I am really trying to not take it with 184. I would be open to an EE class but preferrably one with not too much math but more EE. I havent taken EE 120 so its kind of a problem as a lot of the upper div EE classes have EE 120 as a prereq. </md>

<md>My enrollment time is tommorow and as an upper classmen graduating next semester, I feel pretty im pretty out of luck now. The only upper division I can realistically take is 162 and it wont be feasable to take with the other available upper divs like 189/170 due to being high workload and knowing my own limits. What are my options besides taking an insane workload and taking a gap semester?</md>

Core circuits class isn't offered for years: crickets.

CS classes will be smaller one semester: THE SKY IS FALLING

lol

"EECS leadership hears your concerns regarding the lower projected enrollment capacities. We will in any case ensure that wherever we land with enrollments, students are not hindered from graduating on time."

What would be the suggestion for students who want to take a specific class (CS 189) but the waitlist is ridiculous (almost at 600 people)? Should I give up a slot in another classes' waitlist to wait in CS 189 (at a ridiculous position) or should I just give up on that class and try and stay/get on waitlists for other EECS Upper Divs (since all of them have waitlists at this point)?

history.content:
Dear Students, on behalf of EECS Chair and Associate EECS Chair, please see the following statement on spring 2021 course enrollments.

 

As some of you have noticed, the initial enrollment capacities for SP21 are lower than past semesters. This reduction is the result of significant anticipated funding cuts EECS uses for teaching support staff. Even with remote instruction, we cannot support prior enrollment levels with fewer (u)GSIs. These cuts are still provisional, and we are doing our best to restore funding or restore enrollments by other means. It is not difficult to add additional enrollment later, but it is very difficult and disruptive to reduce enrollments later. Enrollment capacities for SP21 right now may be revised throughout the enrollment period that runs 10/12/20 – 2/2/21.

 

EECS leadership hears your concerns regarding the lower projected enrollment capacities. We will in any case ensure that wherever we land with enrollments, students are not hindered from graduating on time. 

 

Sincerely, 

 

Jeff Bokor 

EECS Chair/EE Division Chair 

 

John Canny 

EECS Associate Chair/CS Division Chair
history.subject: Statement on Spring 2021 Course Enrollments
